table-wrap.anchoringText: An extract from the water discharge limits for Trinidad and Tobago is given in Table 1. The table illustrates the stricter criteria for onshore and nearshore discharge when compared to marine offshore. Of particular interest are the limits for Total Oil and Grease (TO&G) or Oil Concentration and Total Petroleum Hydrocarbons.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Water Discharge Limits for Trinidad and Tobago (Environmental Management Authority, 2001)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water Discharge Limits for Trinidad and Tobago (Environmental Management Authority, 2001)

tr.td: NATE: No Acute Toxic Effects; NSD: No Solid Debris

linkTarget.bib: Environmental Management Authority, 2001 Environmental Management Authority Water Pollution Rules [Book]. - Trinidad: [s.n.], 2001.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The produced water specifications for surface discharge in the Gulf of Mexico are presented in Table 2 below.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Surface Water Discharge Limits for United States Gulf of Mexico (Diagle, 2012) and (United States Environmental Protection Agency, 2012)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Surface Water Discharge Limits for United States Gulf of Mexico (Diagle, 2012) and (United States Environmental Protection Agency, 2012)

tr.td: Note 1: Seven (7) day average minimum and monthly average minimum No Observable Effect Concentration (NOEC) must be greater than or equal to the critical dilution concentration specified in the NPDES general permit (United States Environmental Protection Agency, 2012).

29 mg/L monthly average
42 mg/L daily maximum

Minimum once per month
Samples collected daily

Estimated once per month
Recorded in bbl/day

No free oil discharge
No visible sheen upon daily monitoring, with sheens reported

Quarterly testing if rate > 4,600 bbl/day
Annually if rate < 4,600 bbl/day (Note 1)

linkTarget.bib: Diagle, 2012 Diagle TimothyP. Ultra Deep Water Discharge of Produced Water and/or Solids at the Seabed, RPSEA Contract No. 09121-3100-01 [Report]. - Sugar Land , Texas: RPSEA, 2012.

United States Environmental Protection Agency, 2012 United States Environmental Protection Agency The NPDES General Permit for new and existing sources and new discharges in the offshore subcategory for the western portion of the outer continental shelf of the Gulf of Mexico (GMG290000) [Online]. - 2012. - https://www3.epa.gov/region6/water/npdes/genpermit/gmg290000final/gmg290000finalpermit2012.pdf.

table-wrap.anchoringText: Toxicity measurement, solids and gas measurement and free oil discharge monitoring are functions that are excluded from the scope of sensor development. The full capability of the produced water sensor is given in Table 3.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Produced Water Sensor Measurement Capability (Zhang, 2015)

tr.td: 20 – min 35 °APISensor vendor to provide upper limit, and determine whether 60 °API is possible

td.b: Maximum flow velocity in the discharge pipe (ft/s)

tr.td: Up to 15 desiredFor manufacturer to determine the limit for the specific sensor

td.b: Minimum flow velocity in the discharge pipe (ft/s)

tr.td: Turn-down ratio. If even lower flowrate is needed, discharge system design may include functionalities to achieve a min velocity. Additionally, at very low water production rate, it is likely that the water is transported to topsides to processing.

td.b: Production chemicals in Produced Water – Maximum Concentrations

tr.td:
Total dosage typically up to 2%. Partial partition to water.
However 2% is used to account for occasional overdosing.
Oil based, limited partition to water
Oil based, limited partition to water
Oil based, limited partition to water
Corrosion inhibitor: Dosage normally in the range 5-15 ppm. Oil soluble in most of the cases. So 5 ppm maximum in PW.
Scale inhibitor: aqueous based so mostly in water. Although the concentration value may be high, occasionally overdosing occurs so there is likelihood that this level occurs.

The max concentration from completion fluid lost to formation and brought back by production. Flow back of scale solvent in tubing is non-routine operation which most likely be sent to intervention vessel or host.
Emulsion breaker, or reverse emulsion breaker
Emulsion breaker/reverse emulsion breaker: 10-200 ppm typical dosing range. Highly oil soluble, so maximum in PW 20 ppm (10% of the maximum)
5-25 typical range. Not soluble in water or oil. 5 ppm maximum in PW.

The max concentration from completion fluid lost to formation and brought back by production. This is after the well unloading and ramp-up operation, for which the water is not discharged through the PW system, instead goes through the well clean-up water equipment.
5-15 typical dosing. Water soluble, maximum 15ppm in PW. There are different types of deoilers: coagulant and flocculant.
Typically injected in batch in the water for enhanced oil recovery.
Ca, Mg, Na, Ba, K, Fe
Cl, SO4, CO2, HCO3, F, B(OH)4, Br, CO3, I

linkTarget.bib: Zhang, 2015 Zhang Jianfeng Subsea Produced Water SensorDevelopment, RPSEAContract No. 12121-6301-03 [Report]. - Houston, Texas: RPSEA, 2015.
Diagle, 2012 Diagle TimothyP. Ultra Deep Water Discharge of Produced Water and/or Solids at the Seabed, RPSEA Contract No. 09121-3100-01 [Report]. - Sugar Land , Texas: RPSEA, 2012.

table-wrap.anchoringText: The sensor is designed for use in deepwater applications, where external pressures are much higher than those typically specified for topside instruments. The design specifications for the sensor are given in Table 4. The sensor has a design life of twenty (20) years and will be serviceable, retrievable and re-installable with a working Remote Operated Vehicle (ROV) Class III. The maximum frequency of ROV maintenance operation is four (4) times annually, however, umbilical can also be used to service the sensor without frequency limits, if required.
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: Produced Water Sensor Design Conditions (Zhang, 2015)

tr.td: This is the “survival condition”. Measurement is not required at this condition.

This is the “survival condition”. Measurement is not required at this condition.
Note the special test requirements by API on non-metallic materials such as optical windows.
Sensor functions are required at this condition
Sensor functions are required at this condition
The sensors will be part of a subsea produced water treatment and discharge system.
Very little growth, if any, at 5,000 to 10,000 ft water depth. Assuming none for the prototype designs.

linkTarget.bib: Zhang, 2015 Zhang Jianfeng Subsea Produced Water SensorDevelopment, RPSEAContract No. 12121-6301-03 [Report]. - Houston, Texas: RPSEA, 2015.

table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: Detection and Recovery from Process Changes or Upset Conditions (Zhang, 2015)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Detection and Recovery from Process Changes or Upset Conditions (Zhang, 2015)

tr.td: Change of oil concentration from 15 to 30 mg/L

Detect the change within 15 minutes (Only the detection is required. The requirement of accuracy does not apply to this detection).
Return to normal sensor function within 15 minutes after the produced water discharge process system returns to original performance/quality.

This scenario is about the produced water discharge being still within permit limit but a minor process change has occurred. Detecting such change can be an early warning for operators to check the process status, to prevent further deterioration which may cause the PWD to be over permit limit.
Change of oil concentration from 15 to 100 mg/L, or from 30 to 500 mg/L

Detect the change within 5 minutes (Only the detection is required. The requirement of accuracy does not apply to this detection).
Return to normal sensor function within 30 minutes after the produced water discharge process system returns to original performance/quality.
This scenario is when a process upset has occurred which leads to the produced water discharge to be over permit limit.

linkTarget.bib: Zhang, 2015 Zhang Jianfeng Subsea Produced Water SensorDevelopment, RPSEAContract No. 12121-6301-03 [Report]. - Houston, Texas: RPSEA, 2015.
